abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Energy Access Project
            for Burkina Faso were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was low, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            project implementation can benefit by taking a thorough look
            at human resources of agencies and their preparation to deal
            with the critical tasks of tender design, procurement
            procedures (and the particularities of Bank procurement),
            and financial management. The delays associated with access
            projects should be taken into account at appraisal and built
            into project design by allowing for an initial period of
            project preparation and information dissemination among
            potential beneficiaries. Limiting the number of institutions
            involved in implementation improves the chances for success.
            Monitoring and evaluation (M and E) design and
            implementation should be addressed in detail at preparation
            and early stages of implementation. Planning for a
            beneficiary survey should be thought out upfront and not
            just at the time of project closing.

repnme.cdata!: Burkina Faso - Energy Access Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Energy Access
            Project for Burkina Faso to support Burkina Faso's
            efforts to increase access to, and use of energy services,
            to improve living conditions in selected rural, peri-urban,
            and urban areas by: (a) assisting the government to
            implement its rural electrification strategy to enhance
            productivity and the impact of health and education
            programs; (b) supporting community based sustainable wood
            fuel supply management and introduce alternative household
            fuels to reduce unsustainable pressure on forest resources
            and illnesses induced by indoor air pollution; (c)
            strengthening key sector institutions to create a favorable
            investment environment for more cooperatives and private
            sector participation in energy service delivery initiatives.
            The Project Development Object (PDO) level changes pertain
            to target adjustments for three indicators to align original
            targets with contracts and more realistic projections. The
            three targets have been adjusted as follows : (i) number of
            education  and health facilities in selected areas with
            access to electricity services: from 528 to 214; (ii) number
            of administrative and recreational facilities with access to
            electricity services: from 450 to 303; (iii) number of
            improved wood and charcoal stoves disseminated to
            households: from 250000 to 70000

repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Energy Access Project :
            resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Energy Access Project (EAP) seeks to
            support economic growth and poverty alleviation, and
            increase the rural and urban populations' access to
            electricity services, ensuring a sustainable supply of
            biomass-based energy. The project will also promote
            least-cost and sustainable solutions, through supply and
            demand-side energy management, and through the participation
            of the private sector and communities. Renewable and low
            carbon energies development will be supported, namely by the
            Global Environment Facility and Carbon finance Credits.
            While the project will seek to avoid as possible, or
            minimize reallocation by evaluating all possible
            alternatives, it is foreseen resettlement will nonetheless
            occur. Involuntary resettlement will be conducted in
            accordance with the Bank's operational directive 4.12,
            specifically targeting the most vulnerable groups, to ensure
            affected people benefit from implementation of the project,
            and that their livelihoods are improved, or at least
            restored. Public consultations will be conducted to inform
            populations on their rights concerning resettlement and
            compensation due. Land replacement shall compensate for land
            losses, while housing and structures will be compensated in
            cash, including construction materials; crop losses - crops
            and fruit trees - will be compensated in kind based on its
            productivity, or, in cash at current market values.
            Grievance mechanisms will be in place should conflict occur.
